Situation1: Their family members have recently emphasized the importance of maintaining long-held customs.
Expectation2: Follow the instructions and guidelines provided by the volunteer coordinator
Situation2: An urgent directive from the coordinator outlines mandatory procedures that must be followed to avoid shutting down the service.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, my mother’s words echoing in my mind: “We must never forget our family traditions, especially now.” She had just finished reminding me how important it was to help prepare for the annual family gathering, a ritual that meant everything to my grandparents. As the only child at home, I knew they were counting on me to uphold our customs, to be present, to honor our roots. My phone buzzed. It was a message from the volunteer coordinator: “All volunteers must follow the new safety procedures immediately. If we don’t comply, the service will be shut down.” The urgency in her words was clear—my presence was needed at the community center, and there was no room for negotiation. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing down on me. My family’s expectations pulled me one way, the responsibility to my volunteer team tugged me another. My heart pounded as I stared at the two messages, feeling the pressure mount, knowing I couldn’t possibly meet both demands at once.
